results.title: A Foreign language
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Wolf Koenig, Roman Kroitor and Stanley Jackson
results.brief_description: This film observes, in a Montreal public school, the teaching of English to immigrant children. To thousands of children arriving in Canada from Greece, Italy, France, Germany or Japan, English is “a foreign language.” Under able coaching they begin to understand and even enjoy the vagaries of the English language.

results.title: A Foreign Affair
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “High Office”.
A dictator comes to power in a former British colony. Conditions in his country deteriorate but business opportunities for Britain are good. The program examines how the British government might view the request for a royal visit and how it would react to rumours of an impending coup against the new regime

results.title: A Force more powerful: a century of non-violent conflict
results.creator_credit: Steve York, York Zimmerman and WETA-TV
results.brief_description: Explores the use of nonviolent action in the fight for human rights around the world during the 20th century. Mohandas Gandhi, inspired by the Russian Revolution of 1905, fully believed in nonviolence as a means of fighting back against any form of oppression or brutality. Three broad classes of nonviolent methods exist: nonviolent protest and persuasion, noncooperation, and nonviolent intervention. “A Force more powerful” presents six stories demonstrating successful nonviolent means of overcoming conflict. “India: defying the Crown” 1930-31 - Gandhi led the fight for independence using civil disobedience on a massive scale, challenging the British tax and monopoly on salt. “Nashville: we were warriors” 1960-61 - Students led by Reverend James Lawson staged sit-ins and boycotts to eliminate segregation in Nashville, a city of two races. “Poland: we’ve caught God by the arm” 1980-81 - A strike, organised by Lech Walesa, and the workers in the shipyard at Gdansk led to the birth of the Solidarity movement and the fight for recognition of trade unions. “South Africa: freedom in our lifetime” 1985-86 - Youth organiser, Mkhuseli Jack, brought together the various Black civil action groups and arranged a consumer boycott of the white businesses in Port Elizabeth in an attempt to end apartheid. “Denmark: living with the enemy” 1940-45 - Although the Danish Government proclaimed neutrality status during World War II, they were still occupied by the Nazis. A facade of co-operation covered a growing active resistance, a resistance which eventually led to sabotage and labor strikes. “Chile: defeat of a dictator” 1983-88 - General Augusto Pinochet’s brutal dictatorship and military rule was gradually undermined by the Chilean people staging a national protest day and months and years of nonviolent demonstrations. Contains b&w archival footage. Narrated by Ben Kingsley.

results.title: A Floral pageant
results.brief_description: Victoria celebrates 100 years of self government. Shots of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Government House, but mainly the procession along Elizabeth Street. Beginning title says “Presented by Ted Waterford”.

results.title: A Flickering light in the darkness
results.creator_credit: The Film Front and Tricontinental Film Center
results.brief_description: First in a series of nine animated films on the history of Western civilisation. This episode shows Europe emerging from the Dark Ages into a feudal maze of dukedoms and bishoprics. Covers the emergence of a new class - the merchants, and the development of new trade routes. Suitable for lower secondary levels.

results.title: A Fistful of dynamite = Giu la testa
results.creator_credit: Fulvio Morsella, Rafan Cinematografica, Euro International and Sergio Leone
results.brief_description: Set in the time of the Mexican revolution, Juan (Rod Steiger), a leader of a gang of bandits, meets an IRA explosives expert, Sean Mallory (James Coburn) who is on the run in Mexico to avoid detention by the British. Juan wants Sean to use his explosives skills to help rob a bank but Sean is taken by the cause of the revolutionaries and gets involved with them. A fine example of the spaghetti western: a Ennio Morricone soundtrack, direction by Sergio Leone and great use of widescreen vistas all topped off with action and gritty characters. Cast includes Romolo Valli.

results.title: A Fistful of dollars = Per un pugno di dollari [Widescreen] (S)
results.creator_credit: Jolly Film, Harry Colombo, George Papi and Sergio Leone
results.brief_description: Clint Eastwood plays a cynical gunfighter who comes to a small border town and offers his services to two rivalling gangs. Neither gang is aware of his double play, and each thinks it is using him, but the stranger will outwit them both. This picture was the first instalment in a cycle commonly known as the “Dollars” trilogy, with “For a Few Dollars More” and “The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly” as follow-ups. Although the plot was admittedly borrowed from Kurosawa’s “Yojimbo”, the film contains all of Leone’s trademarks; taciturn characters, precise framing, extreme close-ups, and the haunting music of Ennio Morricone. Cast includes Marianne Koch, John Wells, W. Lukschy and Josef Egger.

results.title: A Fist full of trolleys
results.brief_description: Set in a supermarket car park, this exquisitly framed black and white genre based work references a rich visual culture of photography and cinema. The fierce struggle between man and his environment has been transposed into a stark and familiar urban landscape.

results.title: A Fishy problem
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Astrid Silberman and ACMI
results.brief_description: Astrid Silberman attempts to recreate her family recipe for Gefilte fish. She has trouble deciding whether to follow the traditional recipe or to come up with a new interpretation on the old tradition. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Jewish Museum of Australia.
